nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -259,6 +259,78 @@ Field           Required  Type      Description
 
 There is no limit on field descriptions for either key or message.
 
+Row Encoding
+------------
+
+For key and message, an encoder is used to map message and key data onto table columns.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* ``csv`` - Kafka message is formatted as comma separated message, and fields are mapped to table columns
+* ``avro`` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A table definition file must be defined for the encoder to work.
+
+``csv`` Encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a CSV (comma-separated value)
+line and then converts the formatted values to bytes using UTF-8 encoding.

nodes.bodyText: Slice.toStringUtf8() is not super widely known. I would just say Unicode string encoded in UTF-8
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -259,6 +259,78 @@ Field           Required  Type      Description
 
 There is no limit on field descriptions for either key or message.
 
+Row Encoding
+------------
+
+For key and message, an encoder is used to map message and key data onto table columns.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* ``csv`` - Kafka message is formatted as comma separated message, and fields are mapped to table columns
+* ``avro`` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A table definition file must be defined for the encoder to work.
+
+``csv`` Encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a CSV (comma-separated value)
+line and then converts the formatted values to bytes using UTF-8 encoding.
+
+For fields, the ``type`` and ``mapping`` attributes must be defined:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto data type (see table below for list of supported data types)
+* ``mapping`` - the index of the field in the CSV record
+
+``dataFormat`` and ``formatHint`` are not supported and must be omitted.
+
+Table below lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type`` and encoding scheme:
+
+============================= ================================================
+Presto data type              Encoding rules
+============================= ================================================
+``BIGINT``                    Formatted using Java ``Long.toString()``
+``INTEGER``                   Formatted using Java ``Integer.toString()``
+``SMALLINT``                  Formatted using Java ``Short.toString()``
+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``
+``DOUBLE``                    Formatted using Java ``Double.toString()``
+``REAL``                      Formatted using Java ``Float.toString()``
+``BOOLEAN``                   Formatted using Java ``Boolean.toString()``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``  Formatted using Airlift ``Slice.toStringUtf8()``

@@ -259,6 +259,78 @@ Field           Required  Type      Description
 
 There is no limit on field descriptions for either key or message.
 
+Row Encoding
+------------
+
+For key and message, an encoder is used to map message and key data onto table columns.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* ``csv`` - Kafka message is formatted as comma separated message, and fields are mapped to table columns
+* ``avro`` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A table definition file must be defined for the encoder to work.
+
+``csv`` Encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a CSV (comma-separated value)
+line and then converts the formatted values to bytes using UTF-8 encoding.
+
+For fields, the ``type`` and ``mapping`` attributes must be defined:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto data type (see table below for list of supported data types)
+* ``mapping`` - the index of the field in the CSV record
+
+``dataFormat`` and ``formatHint`` are not supported and must be omitted.
+
+Table below lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type`` and encoding scheme:
+
+============================= ================================================
+Presto data type              Encoding rules
+============================= ================================================
+``BIGINT``                    Formatted using Java ``Long.toString()``
+``INTEGER``                   Formatted using Java ``Integer.toString()``
+``SMALLINT``                  Formatted using Java ``Short.toString()``
+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``
+``DOUBLE``                    Formatted using Java ``Double.toString()``
+``REAL``                      Formatted using Java ``Float.toString()``
+``BOOLEAN``                   Formatted using Java ``Boolean.toString()``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``  Formatted using Airlift ``Slice.toStringUtf8()``
+============================= ================================================
+
+``avro`` Encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The Avro encoder maps the column values according to the Avro schema.
+It converts the column values and Avro schema to bytes and sends them to the Kafka topic.
+Presto does not support schema-less Avro encoding.
+
+For key/message, using ``avro`` encoder, the ``dataSchema`` must be defined.

nodes.bodyText:
This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            This should point to the location of a valid Avro schema file of the message which needs to be encoded. This location can be a remote web server
          
          
            
            (e.g.: ``dataSchema: 'http://example.org/schema/avro_data.avsc'``) or local file system(e.g.: ``dataSchema: '/usr/local/schema/avro_data.avsc'``).
          
          
            
            The encoder fails if this location is not accessible from the Presto coordinator node.
          
          
            
            This should point to the location of a valid Avro schema file matching the messages. This location can be a remote web server
          
          
            
            (e.g.: ``dataSchema: 'http://example.org/schema/avro_data.avsc'``) or local file system(e.g.: ``dataSchema: '/usr/local/schema/avro_data.avsc'``).
          
          
            
            The encoder fails if this location is not accessible from the Presto coordinator node.

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -259,6 +259,78 @@ Field           Required  Type      Description
 
 There is no limit on field descriptions for either key or message.
 
+Row Encoding
+------------
+
+For key and message, an encoder is used to map message and key data onto table columns.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* ``csv`` - Kafka message is formatted as comma separated message, and fields are mapped to table columns
+* ``avro`` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A table definition file must be defined for the encoder to work.
+
+``csv`` Encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a CSV (comma-separated value)
+line and then converts the formatted values to bytes using UTF-8 encoding.
+
+For fields, the ``type`` and ``mapping`` attributes must be defined:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto data type (see table below for list of supported data types)
+* ``mapping`` - the index of the field in the CSV record
+
+``dataFormat`` and ``formatHint`` are not supported and must be omitted.
+
+Table below lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type`` and encoding scheme:
+
+============================= ================================================
+Presto data type              Encoding rules
+============================= ================================================
+``BIGINT``                    Formatted using Java ``Long.toString()``
+``INTEGER``                   Formatted using Java ``Integer.toString()``
+``SMALLINT``                  Formatted using Java ``Short.toString()``
+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``
+``DOUBLE``                    Formatted using Java ``Double.toString()``
+``REAL``                      Formatted using Java ``Float.toString()``
+``BOOLEAN``                   Formatted using Java ``Boolean.toString()``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``  Formatted using Airlift ``Slice.toStringUtf8()``
+============================= ================================================
+
+``avro`` Encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The Avro encoder maps the column values according to the Avro schema.
+It converts the column values and Avro schema to bytes and sends them to the Kafka topic.
+Presto does not support schema-less Avro encoding.
+
+For key/message, using ``avro`` encoder, the ``dataSchema`` must be defined.
+This should point to the location of a valid Avro schema file of the message which needs to be encoded. This location can be a remote web server
+(e.g.: ``dataSchema: 'http://example.org/schema/avro_data.avsc'``) or local file system(e.g.: ``dataSchema: '/usr/local/schema/avro_data.avsc'``).
+The encoder fails if this location is not accessible from the Presto coordinator node.

Technically, the encoder does not send the messages to the topic 😉. Perhaps we can simply say:
This encoder serializes rows to Avro records as defined by the Avro schema.
And details on how columns are mapped to fields are provided below.

nodes.bodyText:
It points to the location of the Avro schema file for the messages.
Files can be retrieved via HTTP or HTTPS from remote server with the syntax dataSchema: 'http://example.org/schema/avro_data.avsc'.  Local files need to be available on all Presto nodes and use a absolute path in the syntax, for example  dataSchema: '/usr/local/schema/avro_data.avsc'.

@@ -259,6 +261,133 @@ Field           Required  Type      Description
 
 There is no limit on field descriptions for either key or message.
 
+Row encoding
+------------
+
+Encoding allows SQL insert statements to be used and defines how table columns in Presto
+map to Kafka key and message data.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* `CSV encoder`_ - Kafka message is formatted as comma separated message, and fields are mapped to table columns
+* `Avro encoder`_ - Kafka message is mapped to Avro fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A table definition file must be defined for the encoder to work. `Table Definition Files`_
+
+CSV encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a line of comma-separated-values (CSV)
+using UTF-8 encoding.
+
+The ``type`` and ``mapping`` attributes must be defined for each field:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - The integer index of the column in the CSV line (the first column is 0, the second is 1, and so on)
+
+``dataFormat`` and ``formatHint`` are not supported and must be omitted.
+
+The following table lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type`` and encoding scheme:
+
+============================= ================================================
+Presto data type              Encoding rules
+============================= ================================================
+``BIGINT``                    Formatted using Java ``Long.toString()``
+``INTEGER``                   Formatted using Java ``Integer.toString()``
+``SMALLINT``                  Formatted using Java ``Short.toString()``
+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``
+``DOUBLE``                    Formatted using Java ``Double.toString()``
+``REAL``                      Formatted using Java ``Float.toString()``
+``BOOLEAN``                   Formatted using Java ``Boolean.toString()``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``  Unicode String encoded in UTF-8
+============================= ================================================

+Kafka inserts
+-------------
+
+The Kafka connector supports the use of SQL ``INSERT INTO`` statements to write data to a Kafka topic.
+Table column data is mapped to Kafka messages as defined in the table definition file, `Table Definition Files`_.
+There are currently three supported data formats for key and message encoding, raw, CSV, and Avro. These data
+formats each have an encoder that handles mapping table column values.
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for a hypothetical "product" table with fields name (VARCHAR), and key (BIGINT):
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO product (name, key) VALUES ('product name', 12345);
+
+Row encoding
+------------
+
+Encoding allows SQL insert statements to be used and defines how table columns in Presto
+map to Kafka key and message data.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* raw encoder - Table columns are mapped to Kafka message as raw bytes
+* CSV encoder - Kafka message is formatted as comma separated message, and fields are mapped to table columns
+* Avro encoder - Kafka message is mapped to Avro fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A table definition file must be defined for the encoder to work. `Table Definition Files`_
+
+raw encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The raw encoder formats the table columns as raw bytes using the mapping information specified in the
+table definition file, `Table Definition Files`_.
+
+For fields, the following attributes are supported:
+
+* ``dataFormat`` - Selects the width of the column data type
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - ``<start>[:<end>]``; start and end position of bytes to convert
+
+The ``dataFormat`` attribute selects the number of bytes converted.
+If absent, ``BYTE`` is assumed. All values are signed.
+
+Supported values are:
+
+* ``BYTE`` - one byte
+* ``SHORT`` - two bytes (big-endian)
+* ``INT`` - four bytes (big-endian)
+* ``LONG`` - eight bytes (big-endian)
+* ``FLOAT`` - four bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+* ``DOUBLE`` - eight bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+
+The ``type`` attribute defines the Presto data type.
+
+Depending on Presto type assigned to column different values of dataFormat can be used:
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      ``dataFormat`` values
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``INTEGER``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``
+``SMALLINT``                          ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``
+``TINYINT``                           ``BYTE``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``BYTE``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+The ``mapping`` attribute specifies the range of the bytes in a key or
+message used for encoding. It can be one or two numbers separated by a colon (``<start>[:<end>]``).
+
+.. note::
+
+    For ``VARCHAR`` types a start and end position must be defined, otherwise there is no way to know how many bytes
+    the message contains. The raw format mapping information is static and cannot be dynamically changed to fit the
+    variable width of some Presto data types.
+
+If only a start position is given:
+
+* For fixed width types the appropriate number of bytes are used for the specified ``dateFormat`` (see above).
+
+If start and end position are given, then:
+
+* For fixed width types the size must be equal to number of bytes used by specified ``dataFormat``.
+* For ``VARCHAR`` all bytes between start (inclusive) and end (exclusive) are used.
+
+If no ``mapping`` attribute is specified, it is equivalent to setting start position to 0 and leaving end position undefined.
+
+Encoding scheme of numeric data types (``BIGINT``, ``INTEGER``, ``SMALLINT``, ``TINYINT``, ``DOUBLE``) is straightforward.
+Table column bytes are encoded to bytes according to either:

+raw encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The raw encoder formats the table columns as raw bytes using the mapping information specified in the
+table definition file, `Table Definition Files`_.
+

+
+* ``dataFormat`` - Selects the width of the column data type
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - ``<start>[:<end>]``; start and end position of bytes to convert
+
+The ``dataFormat`` attribute selects the number of bytes converted.
+If absent, ``BYTE`` is assumed. All values are signed.
+
+Supported values are:
+
+* ``BYTE`` - one byte
+* ``SHORT`` - two bytes (big-endian)
+* ``INT`` - four bytes (big-endian)
+* ``LONG`` - eight bytes (big-endian)
+* ``FLOAT`` - four bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+* ``DOUBLE`` - eight bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+
+The ``type`` attribute defines the Presto data type.
+
+Depending on Presto type assigned to column different values of dataFormat can be used:
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      ``dataFormat`` values
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``INTEGER``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``
+``SMALLINT``                          ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``
+``TINYINT``                           ``BYTE``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``BYTE``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+The ``mapping`` attribute specifies the range of the bytes in a key or
+message used for encoding. It can be one or two numbers separated by a colon (``<start>[:<end>]``).
+
+.. note::
+
+    For ``VARCHAR`` types a start and end position must be defined, otherwise there is no way to know how many bytes
+    the message contains. The raw format mapping information is static and cannot be dynamically changed to fit the
+    variable width of some Presto data types.
+
+If only a start position is given:
+
+* For fixed width types the appropriate number of bytes are used for the specified ``dateFormat`` (see above).
+
+If start and end position are given, then:
+
+* For fixed width types the size must be equal to number of bytes used by specified ``dataFormat``.
+* For ``VARCHAR`` all bytes between start (inclusive) and end (exclusive) are used.
+
+If no ``mapping`` attribute is specified, it is equivalent to setting start position to 0 and leaving end position undefined.
+
+Encoding scheme of numeric data types (``BIGINT``, ``INTEGER``, ``SMALLINT``, ``TINYINT``, ``DOUBLE``) is straightforward.
+Table column bytes are encoded to bytes according to either:
+
+* big-endian encoding (for integer types)
+* IEEE 754 format for (for ``DOUBLE``).
+
+Example raw field definition in a table definition file (`Table Definition Files`_) for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "raw",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "INTEGER",
+                    "dataFormat": "INT"
+                    "mapping": "8"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "SMALLINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "12"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field4",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR(6)",
+                    "dataFormat": "BYTE",
+                    "mapping": "20:26"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_raw_table (field1, field2, field3, field4) VALUES (123456789, 123456, 1234, 'abcdef');
+
+CSV encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a line of comma-separated-values (CSV)
+using UTF-8 encoding.
+
+The ``type`` and ``mapping`` attributes must be defined for each field:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - The integer index of the column in the CSV line (the first column is 0, the second is 1, and so on)
+
+``dataFormat`` and ``formatHint`` are not supported and must be omitted.
+
+The following table lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type`` and encoding scheme:
+
+============================= ================================================
+Presto data type              Encoding rules
+============================= ================================================
+``BIGINT``                    Formatted using Java ``Long.toString()``
+``INTEGER``                   Formatted using Java ``Integer.toString()``
+``SMALLINT``                  Formatted using Java ``Short.toString()``
+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``
+``DOUBLE``                    Formatted using Java ``Double.toString()``
+``REAL``                      Formatted using Java ``Float.toString()``
+``BOOLEAN``                   Formatted using Java ``Boolean.toString()``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``  Unicode String encoded in UTF-8
+============================= ================================================
+
+Example CSV field definition in a table definition file (`Table Definition Files`_) for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "csv",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "2"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_csv_table (field1, field2, field3) VALUES (123456789, "example text", TRUE);

@@ -259,6 +264,430 @@ Field           Required  Type      Description
 
 There is no limit on field descriptions for either key or message.
 
+Kafka inserts
+-------------
+
+The Kafka connector supports the use of :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to write
+data to a Kafka topic. Table column data is mapped to Kafka messages as defined
+in the :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`. There are
+four supported data formats for key and message encoding:
+
+* :ref:`raw format<kafka-raw-encoder>`
+* :ref:`CSV format<kafka-csv-encoder>`
+* :ref:`JSON format<kafka-json-encoder>`
+* :ref:`Avro format<kafka-avro-encoder>`
+
+These data formats each have an encoder that handles mapping table column values.
+Table column values are mapped by the encoders and sent to Kafka topics as bytes.
+
+Presto supports at-least-once delivery for Kafka producers. This means that
+messages are guaranteed to be sent to Kafka topics at least once. If a producer
+acknowledgement times out or if the producer receives an error it might retry
+sending the message. This could result in a duplicate message being sent to the
+Kafka topic.
+
+The Kafka connector does not allow the user to define which partition to send a
+message to. If a key is inserted with the message the producer will use a hash
+algorithm to decide which partition to send the message to. The same key will
+always be assigned the same partition.
+
+Row encoding
+------------
+
+Encoding allows :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to be used and defines how table
+columns in Presto map to Kafka key and message data.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* :ref:`raw encoder<kafka-raw-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to Kafka
+  message as raw bytes
+* :ref:`CSV encoder<kafka-csv-encoder>` - Kafka message is formatted as comma
+  separated value
+* :ref:`JSON encoder<kafka-json-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to JSON
+  fields
+* :ref:`Avro encoder<kafka-avro-encoder>` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro
+  fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` must be defined
+    for the encoder to work.
+
+.. _kafka-raw-encoder:
+
+raw encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

@@ -259,6 +264,430 @@ Field           Required  Type      Description
 
 There is no limit on field descriptions for either key or message.
 
+Kafka inserts
+-------------
+
+The Kafka connector supports the use of :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to write
+data to a Kafka topic. Table column data is mapped to Kafka messages as defined
+in the :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`. There are
+four supported data formats for key and message encoding:
+
+* :ref:`raw format<kafka-raw-encoder>`
+* :ref:`CSV format<kafka-csv-encoder>`
+* :ref:`JSON format<kafka-json-encoder>`
+* :ref:`Avro format<kafka-avro-encoder>`
+
+These data formats each have an encoder that handles mapping table column values.
+Table column values are mapped by the encoders and sent to Kafka topics as bytes.
+
+Presto supports at-least-once delivery for Kafka producers. This means that
+messages are guaranteed to be sent to Kafka topics at least once. If a producer
+acknowledgement times out or if the producer receives an error it might retry
+sending the message. This could result in a duplicate message being sent to the
+Kafka topic.
+
+The Kafka connector does not allow the user to define which partition to send a
+message to. If a key is inserted with the message the producer will use a hash
+algorithm to decide which partition to send the message to. The same key will
+always be assigned the same partition.
+
+Row encoding
+------------
+
+Encoding allows :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to be used and defines how table
+columns in Presto map to Kafka key and message data.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* :ref:`raw encoder<kafka-raw-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to Kafka
+  message as raw bytes
+* :ref:`CSV encoder<kafka-csv-encoder>` - Kafka message is formatted as comma
+  separated value
+* :ref:`JSON encoder<kafka-json-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to JSON
+  fields
+* :ref:`Avro encoder<kafka-avro-encoder>` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro
+  fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` must be defined
+    for the encoder to work.
+
+.. _kafka-raw-encoder:
+
+raw encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The raw encoder formats the table columns as raw bytes using the mapping
+information specified in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`.
+
+The following field attributes are supported:
+
+* ``dataFormat`` - Selects the width of the column data type
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - ``<start>[:<end>]``; start and end position of bytes to convert
+
+The ``dataFormat`` attribute selects the number of bytes converted.
+If absent, ``BYTE`` is assumed. All values are signed.
+
+Supported values are:
+
+* ``BYTE`` - one byte
+* ``SHORT`` - two bytes (big-endian)
+* ``INT`` - four bytes (big-endian)
+* ``LONG`` - eight bytes (big-endian)
+* ``FLOAT`` - four bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+* ``DOUBLE`` - eight bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+
+The ``type`` attribute defines the Presto data type.
+
+Depending on Presto type assigned to column different values of ``dataFormat``
+can be used:
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      ``dataFormat`` values
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``INTEGER``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``
+``SMALLINT``                          ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``
+``TINYINT``                           ``BYTE``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``BYTE``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+The ``mapping`` attribute specifies the range of bytes in a key or
+message used for encoding. It can be one or two numbers separated by a colon
+(``<start>[:<end>]``).
+
+.. note::
+
+    For ``VARCHAR`` types a start and end position must be defined. Otherwise
+    there is no way to know how many bytes the message contains. The raw format
+    mapping information is static and cannot be dynamically changed to fit the
+    variable width of some Presto data types.
+
+If only a start position is given:
+
+* For fixed width types the appropriate number of bytes are used for the
+  specified ``dateFormat`` (see above).
+
+If start and end position are given, then:
+
+* For fixed width types the size must be equal to number of bytes used by
+  specified ``dataFormat``.
+* For ``VARCHAR`` all bytes between start (inclusive) and end (exclusive) are
+  used.
+
+.. note::
+
+    At the very least a start value must be present in the mapping for encoding
+    to work.
+
+Encoding scheme of numeric data types (``BIGINT``, ``INTEGER``, ``SMALLINT``,
+``TINYINT``, ``DOUBLE``) is straightforward. Table column values are encoded to
+bytes according to either:
+
+* big-endian encoding (for integer types)
+* IEEE 754 format for (for ``DOUBLE``).
+
+Example raw field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "raw",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "INTEGER",
+                    "dataFormat": "INT"
+                    "mapping": "8"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "SMALLINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "12"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field4",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR(6)",
+                    "dataFormat": "BYTE",
+                    "mapping": "20:26"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+.. note::
+
+    Columns should be defined in the same order they are mapped. There can be
+    no gaps or overlaps between column mappings. The width of the column as
+    defined by the column mapping must be equivalent to the width of the
+    ``dataFormat`` for all types except for variable width types.
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_raw_table (field1, field2, field3, field4)
+      VALUES (123456789, 123456, 1234, 'abcdef');
+
+.. note::
+
+    When inserting variable width types the value must be exactly equal to the
+    width defined in the table definition file. If the inserted value is longer
+    it gets truncated, resulting in data loss. If the inserted value is shorter
+    the decoder will not be able to properly read the value because there is no
+    defined padding character. Due to these constraints the encoder fails if the
+    width of the inserted value is not equal to the mapping width.
+
+.. _kafka-csv-encoder:
+
+CSV encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

+===================================== =======================================

+``INTEGER``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``
+``SMALLINT``                          ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``
+``TINYINT``                           ``BYTE``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``

+===================================== =======================================

+            "fields": [

+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "INTEGER",
+                    "dataFormat": "INT"
+                    "mapping": "8"
+                },

+                    "mapping": "12"

+.. _kafka-csv-encoder:
+
+CSV encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a line of
+comma-separated-values (CSV) using UTF-8 encoding.
+
+.. note::
+
+    The CSV line is formatted with a comma ',' as the column delimiter
+
+The ``type`` and ``mapping`` attributes must be defined for each field:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - The integer index of the column in the CSV line (the first
+  column is 0, the second is 1, and so on)
+
+``dataFormat`` and ``formatHint`` are not supported and must be omitted.
+
+The following table lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type``
+and encoding scheme:
+
+============================= ================================================
+Presto data type              Encoding rules
+============================= ================================================
+``BIGINT``                    Formatted using Java ``Long.toString()``
+``INTEGER``                   Formatted using Java ``Integer.toString()``
+``SMALLINT``                  Formatted using Java ``Short.toString()``
+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``
+``DOUBLE``                    Formatted using Java ``Double.toString()``
+``REAL``                      Formatted using Java ``Float.toString()``
+``BOOLEAN``                   Formatted using Java ``Boolean.toString()``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``  Unicode String encoded in UTF-8
+============================= ================================================
+
+Example CSV field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "csv",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "2"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_csv_table (field1, field2, field3)
+      VALUES (123456789, 'example text', TRUE);
+
+.. _kafka-json-encoder:
+
+JSON encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "INTEGER",
+                    "dataFormat": "INT"
+                    "mapping": "8"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "SMALLINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "12"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field4",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR(6)",
+                    "dataFormat": "BYTE",
+                    "mapping": "20:26"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+.. note::
+
+    Columns should be defined in the same order they are mapped. There can be
+    no gaps or overlaps between column mappings. The width of the column as
+    defined by the column mapping must be equivalent to the width of the
+    ``dataFormat`` for all types except for variable width types.
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_raw_table (field1, field2, field3, field4)
+      VALUES (123456789, 123456, 1234, 'abcdef');
+
+.. note::
+
+    When inserting variable width types the value must be exactly equal to the
+    width defined in the table definition file. If the inserted value is longer
+    it gets truncated, resulting in data loss. If the inserted value is shorter
+    the decoder will not be able to properly read the value because there is no
+    defined padding character. Due to these constraints the encoder fails if the
+    width of the inserted value is not equal to the mapping width.
+
+.. _kafka-csv-encoder:
+
+CSV encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a line of
+comma-separated-values (CSV) using UTF-8 encoding.
+
+.. note::
+
+    The CSV line is formatted with a comma ',' as the column delimiter
+
+The ``type`` and ``mapping`` attributes must be defined for each field:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - The integer index of the column in the CSV line (the first
+  column is 0, the second is 1, and so on)
+
+``dataFormat`` and ``formatHint`` are not supported and must be omitted.
+
+The following table lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type``
+and encoding scheme:
+
+============================= ================================================
+Presto data type              Encoding rules
+============================= ================================================
+``BIGINT``                    Formatted using Java ``Long.toString()``
+``INTEGER``                   Formatted using Java ``Integer.toString()``
+``SMALLINT``                  Formatted using Java ``Short.toString()``
+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``
+``DOUBLE``                    Formatted using Java ``Double.toString()``
+``REAL``                      Formatted using Java ``Float.toString()``
+``BOOLEAN``                   Formatted using Java ``Boolean.toString()``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``  Unicode String encoded in UTF-8
+============================= ================================================
+
+Example CSV field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "csv",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "2"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_csv_table (field1, field2, field3)
+      VALUES (123456789, 'example text', TRUE);
+
+.. _kafka-json-encoder:
+
+JSON encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The JSON encoder maps table columns to JSON fields defined in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` according to
+:rfc:`4627`.
+
+For fields, the following attributes are supported:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto type of column.
+* ``mapping`` - slash-separated list of field names to select a field from the
+  JSON object
+
+The following Presto data types are supported by the JSON encoder
+
+* ``BIGINT``
+* ``INTEGER``
+* ``SMALLINT``
+* ``TINYINT``
+* ``DOUBLE``
+* ``REAL``
+* ``BOOLEAN``
+* ``VARCHAR``
+
+Example JSON field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "json",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "field1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "field2"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "field3"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_json_table (field1, field2, field3)
+      VALUES (123456789, 'example text', TRUE);
+
+.. _kafka-avro-encoder:
+
+Avro encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

@@ -259,6 +264,430 @@ Field           Required  Type      Description
 
 There is no limit on field descriptions for either key or message.
 
+Kafka inserts
+-------------
+
+The Kafka connector supports the use of :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to write
+data to a Kafka topic. Table column data is mapped to Kafka messages as defined
+in the :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`. There are
+four supported data formats for key and message encoding:
+
+* :ref:`raw format<kafka-raw-encoder>`
+* :ref:`CSV format<kafka-csv-encoder>`
+* :ref:`JSON format<kafka-json-encoder>`
+* :ref:`Avro format<kafka-avro-encoder>`
+
+These data formats each have an encoder that handles mapping table column values.
+Table column values are mapped by the encoders and sent to Kafka topics as bytes.
+
+Presto supports at-least-once delivery for Kafka producers. This means that
+messages are guaranteed to be sent to Kafka topics at least once. If a producer
+acknowledgement times out or if the producer receives an error it might retry
+sending the message. This could result in a duplicate message being sent to the
+Kafka topic.
+
+The Kafka connector does not allow the user to define which partition to send a
+message to. If a key is inserted with the message the producer will use a hash
+algorithm to decide which partition to send the message to. The same key will
+always be assigned the same partition.
+
+Row encoding
+------------
+
+Encoding allows :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to be used and defines how table
+columns in Presto map to Kafka key and message data.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* :ref:`raw encoder<kafka-raw-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to Kafka
+  message as raw bytes
+* :ref:`CSV encoder<kafka-csv-encoder>` - Kafka message is formatted as comma
+  separated value
+* :ref:`JSON encoder<kafka-json-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to JSON
+  fields
+* :ref:`Avro encoder<kafka-avro-encoder>` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro
+  fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` must be defined
+    for the encoder to work.
+
+.. _kafka-raw-encoder:
+
+raw encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The raw encoder formats the table columns as raw bytes using the mapping
+information specified in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`.
+
+The following field attributes are supported:
+
+* ``dataFormat`` - Selects the width of the column data type
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - ``<start>[:<end>]``; start and end position of bytes to convert
+
+The ``dataFormat`` attribute selects the number of bytes converted.
+If absent, ``BYTE`` is assumed. All values are signed.
+
+Supported values are:
+
+* ``BYTE`` - one byte
+* ``SHORT`` - two bytes (big-endian)
+* ``INT`` - four bytes (big-endian)
+* ``LONG`` - eight bytes (big-endian)
+* ``FLOAT`` - four bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+* ``DOUBLE`` - eight bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+
+The ``type`` attribute defines the Presto data type.
+
+Depending on Presto type assigned to column different values of ``dataFormat``
+can be used:
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      ``dataFormat`` values
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``INTEGER``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``
+``SMALLINT``                          ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``
+``TINYINT``                           ``BYTE``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``BYTE``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+The ``mapping`` attribute specifies the range of bytes in a key or
+message used for encoding. It can be one or two numbers separated by a colon
+(``<start>[:<end>]``).
+
+.. note::
+
+    For ``VARCHAR`` types a start and end position must be defined. Otherwise
+    there is no way to know how many bytes the message contains. The raw format
+    mapping information is static and cannot be dynamically changed to fit the
+    variable width of some Presto data types.
+
+If only a start position is given:
+
+* For fixed width types the appropriate number of bytes are used for the
+  specified ``dateFormat`` (see above).
+
+If start and end position are given, then:
+
+* For fixed width types the size must be equal to number of bytes used by
+  specified ``dataFormat``.
+* For ``VARCHAR`` all bytes between start (inclusive) and end (exclusive) are
+  used.
+
+.. note::
+
+    At the very least a start value must be present in the mapping for encoding
+    to work.
+
+Encoding scheme of numeric data types (``BIGINT``, ``INTEGER``, ``SMALLINT``,
+``TINYINT``, ``DOUBLE``) is straightforward. Table column values are encoded to
+bytes according to either:
+
+* big-endian encoding (for integer types)
+* IEEE 754 format for (for ``DOUBLE``).
+
+Example raw field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "raw",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "INTEGER",
+                    "dataFormat": "INT"
+                    "mapping": "8"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "SMALLINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "12"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field4",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR(6)",
+                    "dataFormat": "BYTE",
+                    "mapping": "20:26"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+.. note::
+
+    Columns should be defined in the same order they are mapped. There can be
+    no gaps or overlaps between column mappings. The width of the column as
+    defined by the column mapping must be equivalent to the width of the
+    ``dataFormat`` for all types except for variable width types.
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_raw_table (field1, field2, field3, field4)
+      VALUES (123456789, 123456, 1234, 'abcdef');
+
+.. note::
+
+    When inserting variable width types the value must be exactly equal to the
+    width defined in the table definition file. If the inserted value is longer
+    it gets truncated, resulting in data loss. If the inserted value is shorter
+    the decoder will not be able to properly read the value because there is no
+    defined padding character. Due to these constraints the encoder fails if the
+    width of the inserted value is not equal to the mapping width.
+
+.. _kafka-csv-encoder:
+
+CSV encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a line of
+comma-separated-values (CSV) using UTF-8 encoding.
+
+.. note::
+
+    The CSV line is formatted with a comma ',' as the column delimiter
+
+The ``type`` and ``mapping`` attributes must be defined for each field:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - The integer index of the column in the CSV line (the first
+  column is 0, the second is 1, and so on)
+
+``dataFormat`` and ``formatHint`` are not supported and must be omitted.
+
+The following table lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type``
+and encoding scheme:
+
+============================= ================================================
+Presto data type              Encoding rules
+============================= ================================================
+``BIGINT``                    Formatted using Java ``Long.toString()``
+``INTEGER``                   Formatted using Java ``Integer.toString()``
+``SMALLINT``                  Formatted using Java ``Short.toString()``
+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``
+``DOUBLE``                    Formatted using Java ``Double.toString()``
+``REAL``                      Formatted using Java ``Float.toString()``
+``BOOLEAN``                   Formatted using Java ``Boolean.toString()``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``  Unicode String encoded in UTF-8
+============================= ================================================
+
+Example CSV field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "csv",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "2"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_csv_table (field1, field2, field3)
+      VALUES (123456789, 'example text', TRUE);
+
+.. _kafka-json-encoder:
+
+JSON encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The JSON encoder maps table columns to JSON fields defined in the

+                    "name": "field1",

+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "field2"
+                },
+                {

+                    "mapping": "field3"
+                }
+            ]

+

+in the :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`. There are
+four supported data formats for key and message encoding:
+
+* :ref:`raw format<raw-encoder>`
+* :ref:`CSV format<csv-encoder>`
+* :ref:`JSON format<json-encoder>`
+* :ref:`Avro format<avro-encoder>`
+
+These data formats each have an encoder that handles mapping table column values.
+Table column values are mapped by the encoders and sent to Kafka topics as bytes.
+
+Presto supports at-least-once delivery for Kafka producers. This means that
+messages are guaranteed to be sent to Kafka topics at least once. If a producer
+acknowledgement times out or if the producer receives an error it might retry
+sending the message. This could result in a duplicate message being sent to the
+Kafka topic.
+
+The Kafka connector does not allow the user to define which partition to send a
+message to. If a key is inserted with the message the producer will use a hash
+algorithm to decide which partition to send the message to. The same key will
+always be assigned the same partition.
+
+Row encoding
+------------
+
+Encoding allows :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to be used and defines how table
+columns in Presto map to Kafka key and message data.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* :ref:`raw encoder<raw-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to Kafka
+  message as raw bytes
+* :ref:`CSV encoder<csv-encoder>` - Kafka message is formatted as comma
+  separated value
+* :ref:`JSON encoder<json-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to JSON
+  fields
+* :ref:`Avro encoder<avro-encoder>` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro

+The Kafka connector supports the use of :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to write

+The Kafka connector supports the use of :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to write
+data to a Kafka topic. Table column data is mapped to Kafka messages as defined
+in the :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`. There are
+four supported data formats for key and message encoding:
+
+* :ref:`raw format<raw-encoder>`
+* :ref:`CSV format<csv-encoder>`
+* :ref:`JSON format<json-encoder>`
+* :ref:`Avro format<avro-encoder>`
+
+These data formats each have an encoder that handles mapping table column values.
+Table column values are mapped by the encoders and sent to Kafka topics as bytes.
+
+Presto supports at-least-once delivery for Kafka producers. This means that
+messages are guaranteed to be sent to Kafka topics at least once. If a producer
+acknowledgement times out or if the producer receives an error it might retry
+sending the message. This could result in a duplicate message being sent to the
+Kafka topic.
+
+The Kafka connector does not allow the user to define which partition to send a
+message to. If a key is inserted with the message the producer will use a hash
+algorithm to decide which partition to send the message to. The same key will
+always be assigned the same partition.
+
+Row encoding
+------------
+
+Encoding allows :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to be used and defines how table
+columns in Presto map to Kafka key and message data.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* :ref:`raw encoder<raw-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to Kafka
+  message as raw bytes
+* :ref:`CSV encoder<csv-encoder>` - Kafka message is formatted as comma
+  separated value
+* :ref:`JSON encoder<json-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to JSON
+  fields
+* :ref:`Avro encoder<avro-encoder>` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro
+  fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` must be defined
+    for the encoder to work.
+
+.. _raw-encoder:
+
+raw encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The raw encoder formats the table columns as raw bytes using the mapping
+information specified in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`.
+
+The following field attributes are supported:
+
+* ``dataFormat`` - Selects the width of the column data type
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - ``<start>[:<end>]``; start and end position of bytes to convert
+
+The ``dataFormat`` attribute selects the number of bytes converted.
+If absent, ``BYTE`` is assumed. All values are signed.
+
+Supported values are:
+
+* ``BYTE`` - one byte
+* ``SHORT`` - two bytes (big-endian)
+* ``INT`` - four bytes (big-endian)
+* ``LONG`` - eight bytes (big-endian)
+* ``FLOAT`` - four bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+* ``DOUBLE`` - eight bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+
+The ``type`` attribute defines the Presto data type.
+
+Depending on Presto type assigned to column different values of ``dataFormat``
+can be used:
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      ``dataFormat`` values
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``INTEGER``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``
+``SMALLINT``                          ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``
+``TINYINT``                           ``BYTE``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``BYTE``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+The ``mapping`` attribute specifies the range of bytes in a key or
+message used for encoding. It can be one or two numbers separated by a colon
+(``<start>[:<end>]``).
+
+.. note::
+
+    For ``VARCHAR`` types a start and end position must be defined. Otherwise
+    there is no way to know how many bytes the message contains. The raw format
+    mapping information is static and cannot be dynamically changed to fit the
+    variable width of some Presto data types.
+
+If only a start position is given:
+
+* For fixed width types the appropriate number of bytes are used for the
+  specified ``dateFormat`` (see above).
+
+If start and end position are given, then:
+
+* For fixed width types the size must be equal to number of bytes used by
+  specified ``dataFormat``.
+* For ``VARCHAR`` all bytes between start (inclusive) and end (exclusive) are
+  used.
+
+.. note::

nodes.bodyText: We could "guess" the width of columns with a defined dataFormat and compute the start position of columns based on the previous widths, but the decoder doesn't do this. The raw format is very specific about how data has to be serialized, and there isn't really any room for error. I didn't want to make any big changes to the raw format when implementing the encoder. The raw format needs to be rethought, I figured that would be better left for a future pr.

+information specified in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`.
+
+The following field attributes are supported:
+
+* ``dataFormat`` - Selects the width of the column data type
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - ``<start>[:<end>]``; start and end position of bytes to convert
+
+The ``dataFormat`` attribute selects the number of bytes converted.
+If absent, ``BYTE`` is assumed. All values are signed.
+
+Supported values are:
+
+* ``BYTE`` - one byte
+* ``SHORT`` - two bytes (big-endian)
+* ``INT`` - four bytes (big-endian)
+* ``LONG`` - eight bytes (big-endian)
+* ``FLOAT`` - four bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+* ``DOUBLE`` - eight bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+
+The ``type`` attribute defines the Presto data type.
+
+Depending on Presto type assigned to column different values of ``dataFormat``
+can be used:
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      ``dataFormat`` values
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``INTEGER``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``
+``SMALLINT``                          ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``
+``TINYINT``                           ``BYTE``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``BYTE``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+The ``mapping`` attribute specifies the range of bytes in a key or
+message used for encoding. It can be one or two numbers separated by a colon
+(``<start>[:<end>]``).
+
+.. note::
+
+    For ``VARCHAR`` types a start and end position must be defined. Otherwise
+    there is no way to know how many bytes the message contains. The raw format
+    mapping information is static and cannot be dynamically changed to fit the
+    variable width of some Presto data types.
+
+If only a start position is given:
+
+* For fixed width types the appropriate number of bytes are used for the
+  specified ``dateFormat`` (see above).
+
+If start and end position are given, then:
+
+* For fixed width types the size must be equal to number of bytes used by
+  specified ``dataFormat``.
+* For ``VARCHAR`` all bytes between start (inclusive) and end (exclusive) are
+  used.
+
+.. note::
+
+    At the very least a start value must be present in the mapping for encoding
+    to work.
+
+Encoding scheme of numeric data types (``BIGINT``, ``INTEGER``, ``SMALLINT``,
+``TINYINT``, ``DOUBLE``) is straightforward. Table column values are encoded to
+bytes according to either:
+
+* big-endian encoding (for integer types)
+* IEEE 754 format for (for ``DOUBLE``).
+
+Example raw field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none

+in the :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`. There are
+four supported data formats for key and message encoding:
+
+* :ref:`raw format<raw-encoder>`
+* :ref:`CSV format<csv-encoder>`
+* :ref:`JSON format<json-encoder>`
+* :ref:`Avro format<avro-encoder>`
+
+These data formats each have an encoder that handles mapping table column values.
+Table column values are mapped by the encoders and sent to Kafka topics as bytes.
+
+Presto supports at-least-once delivery for Kafka producers. This means that
+messages are guaranteed to be sent to Kafka topics at least once. If a producer
+acknowledgement times out or if the producer receives an error it might retry
+sending the message. This could result in a duplicate message being sent to the
+Kafka topic.
+
+The Kafka connector does not allow the user to define which partition to send a
+message to. If a key is inserted with the message the producer will use a hash
+algorithm to decide which partition to send the message to. The same key will
+always be assigned the same partition.
+
+Row encoding
+------------
+
+Encoding allows :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to be used and defines how table
+columns in Presto map to Kafka key and message data.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* :ref:`raw encoder<raw-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to Kafka
+  message as raw bytes
+* :ref:`CSV encoder<csv-encoder>` - Kafka message is formatted as comma
+  separated value
+* :ref:`JSON encoder<json-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to JSON
+  fields
+* :ref:`Avro encoder<avro-encoder>` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro
+  fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` must be defined
+    for the encoder to work.
+
+.. _raw-encoder:
+
+raw encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The raw encoder formats the table columns as raw bytes using the mapping
+information specified in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`.
+
+The following field attributes are supported:
+
+* ``dataFormat`` - Selects the width of the column data type
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - ``<start>[:<end>]``; start and end position of bytes to convert
+
+The ``dataFormat`` attribute selects the number of bytes converted.
+If absent, ``BYTE`` is assumed. All values are signed.
+
+Supported values are:
+
+* ``BYTE`` - one byte
+* ``SHORT`` - two bytes (big-endian)
+* ``INT`` - four bytes (big-endian)
+* ``LONG`` - eight bytes (big-endian)
+* ``FLOAT`` - four bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+* ``DOUBLE`` - eight bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+
+The ``type`` attribute defines the Presto data type.
+
+Depending on Presto type assigned to column different values of ``dataFormat``
+can be used:
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      ``dataFormat`` values
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``INTEGER``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``
+``SMALLINT``                          ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``
+``TINYINT``                           ``BYTE``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``BYTE``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+The ``mapping`` attribute specifies the range of bytes in a key or
+message used for encoding. It can be one or two numbers separated by a colon
+(``<start>[:<end>]``).
+
+.. note::
+
+    For ``VARCHAR`` types a start and end position must be defined. Otherwise
+    there is no way to know how many bytes the message contains. The raw format
+    mapping information is static and cannot be dynamically changed to fit the
+    variable width of some Presto data types.
+
+If only a start position is given:
+
+* For fixed width types the appropriate number of bytes are used for the
+  specified ``dateFormat`` (see above).
+
+If start and end position are given, then:
+
+* For fixed width types the size must be equal to number of bytes used by
+  specified ``dataFormat``.
+* For ``VARCHAR`` all bytes between start (inclusive) and end (exclusive) are
+  used.
+
+.. note::
+
+    At the very least a start value must be present in the mapping for encoding
+    to work.
+
+Encoding scheme of numeric data types (``BIGINT``, ``INTEGER``, ``SMALLINT``,
+``TINYINT``, ``DOUBLE``) is straightforward. Table column values are encoded to
+bytes according to either:
+
+* big-endian encoding (for integer types)
+* IEEE 754 format for (for ``DOUBLE``).
+
+Example raw field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "raw",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "INTEGER",
+                    "dataFormat": "INT"
+                    "mapping": "8"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "SMALLINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "12"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field4",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR(6)",
+                    "dataFormat": "BYTE",
+                    "mapping": "20:26"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+.. note::
+
+    Columns should be defined in the same order they are mapped. There can be
+    no gaps or overlaps between column mappings. The width of the column as
+    defined by the column mapping must be equivalent to the width of the
+    ``dataFormat`` for all types except for variable width types.
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:

@@ -259,6 +264,430 @@ Field           Required  Type      Description
 
 There is no limit on field descriptions for either key or message.
 
+Kafka inserts
+-------------
+
+The Kafka connector supports the use of :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to write
+data to a Kafka topic. Table column data is mapped to Kafka messages as defined
+in the :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`. There are
+four supported data formats for key and message encoding:
+
+* :ref:`raw format<raw-encoder>`
+* :ref:`CSV format<csv-encoder>`
+* :ref:`JSON format<json-encoder>`
+* :ref:`Avro format<avro-encoder>`
+
+These data formats each have an encoder that handles mapping table column values.
+Table column values are mapped by the encoders and sent to Kafka topics as bytes.
+
+Presto supports at-least-once delivery for Kafka producers. This means that
+messages are guaranteed to be sent to Kafka topics at least once. If a producer
+acknowledgement times out or if the producer receives an error it might retry
+sending the message. This could result in a duplicate message being sent to the
+Kafka topic.
+
+The Kafka connector does not allow the user to define which partition to send a
+message to. If a key is inserted with the message the producer will use a hash
+algorithm to decide which partition to send the message to. The same key will
+always be assigned the same partition.
+
+Row encoding
+------------
+
+Encoding allows :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to be used and defines how table
+columns in Presto map to Kafka key and message data.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* :ref:`raw encoder<raw-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to Kafka
+  message as raw bytes
+* :ref:`CSV encoder<csv-encoder>` - Kafka message is formatted as comma
+  separated value
+* :ref:`JSON encoder<json-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to JSON
+  fields
+* :ref:`Avro encoder<avro-encoder>` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro
+  fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` must be defined
+    for the encoder to work.
+
+.. _raw-encoder:
+
+raw encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The raw encoder formats the table columns as raw bytes using the mapping
+information specified in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`.
+
+The following field attributes are supported:
+
+* ``dataFormat`` - Selects the width of the column data type
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - ``<start>[:<end>]``; start and end position of bytes to convert
+
+The ``dataFormat`` attribute selects the number of bytes converted.
+If absent, ``BYTE`` is assumed. All values are signed.
+
+Supported values are:
+
+* ``BYTE`` - one byte
+* ``SHORT`` - two bytes (big-endian)
+* ``INT`` - four bytes (big-endian)
+* ``LONG`` - eight bytes (big-endian)
+* ``FLOAT`` - four bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+* ``DOUBLE`` - eight bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+
+The ``type`` attribute defines the Presto data type.
+
+Depending on Presto type assigned to column different values of ``dataFormat``
+can be used:
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      ``dataFormat`` values
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``INTEGER``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``
+``SMALLINT``                          ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``
+``TINYINT``                           ``BYTE``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``BYTE``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+The ``mapping`` attribute specifies the range of bytes in a key or
+message used for encoding. It can be one or two numbers separated by a colon
+(``<start>[:<end>]``).
+
+.. note::
+
+    For ``VARCHAR`` types a start and end position must be defined. Otherwise
+    there is no way to know how many bytes the message contains. The raw format
+    mapping information is static and cannot be dynamically changed to fit the
+    variable width of some Presto data types.
+
+If only a start position is given:
+
+* For fixed width types the appropriate number of bytes are used for the
+  specified ``dateFormat`` (see above).
+
+If start and end position are given, then:
+
+* For fixed width types the size must be equal to number of bytes used by
+  specified ``dataFormat``.
+* For ``VARCHAR`` all bytes between start (inclusive) and end (exclusive) are
+  used.
+
+.. note::
+
+    At the very least a start value must be present in the mapping for encoding
+    to work.
+
+Encoding scheme of numeric data types (``BIGINT``, ``INTEGER``, ``SMALLINT``,
+``TINYINT``, ``DOUBLE``) is straightforward. Table column values are encoded to
+bytes according to either:
+
+* big-endian encoding (for integer types)
+* IEEE 754 format for (for ``DOUBLE``).
+
+Example raw field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "raw",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "INTEGER",
+                    "dataFormat": "INT"
+                    "mapping": "8"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "SMALLINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "12"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field4",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR(6)",
+                    "dataFormat": "BYTE",
+                    "mapping": "20:26"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+.. note::
+
+    Columns should be defined in the same order they are mapped. There can be
+    no gaps or overlaps between column mappings. The width of the column as
+    defined by the column mapping must be equivalent to the width of the
+    ``dataFormat`` for all types except for variable width types.
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_raw_table (field1, field2, field3, field4)
+      VALUES (123456789, 123456, 1234, 'abcdef');
+
+.. note::
+
+    When inserting variable width types the value must be exactly equal to the
+    width defined in the table definition file. If the inserted value is longer
+    it gets truncated, resulting in data loss. If the inserted value is shorter
+    the decoder will not be able to properly read the value because there is no
+    defined padding character. Due to these constraints the encoder fails if the
+    width of the inserted value is not equal to the mapping width.
+
+.. _csv-encoder:
+
+CSV encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a line of
+comma-separated-values (CSV) using UTF-8 encoding.
+
+.. note::
+
+    The CSV line is formatted with a comma ',' as the column delimiter
+
+The ``type`` and ``mapping`` attributes must be defined for each field:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - The integer index of the column in the CSV line (the first
+  column is 0, the second is 1, and so on)
+
+``dataFormat`` and ``formatHint`` are not supported and must be omitted.
+
+The following table lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type``
+and encoding scheme:
+
+============================= ================================================
+Presto data type              Encoding rules
+============================= ================================================
+``BIGINT``                    Formatted using Java ``Long.toString()``
