@@ -259,6 +264,430 @@ Field           Required  Type      Description
 
 There is no limit on field descriptions for either key or message.
 
+Kafka inserts
+-------------
+
+The Kafka connector supports the use of :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to write
+data to a Kafka topic. Table column data is mapped to Kafka messages as defined
+in the :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`. There are
+four supported data formats for key and message encoding:
+
+* :ref:`raw format<raw-encoder>`
+* :ref:`CSV format<csv-encoder>`
+* :ref:`JSON format<json-encoder>`
+* :ref:`Avro format<avro-encoder>`
+
+These data formats each have an encoder that handles mapping table column values.
+Table column values are mapped by the encoders and sent to Kafka topics as bytes.
+
+Presto supports at-least-once delivery for Kafka producers. This means that
+messages are guaranteed to be sent to Kafka topics at least once. If a producer
+acknowledgement times out or if the producer receives an error it might retry
+sending the message. This could result in a duplicate message being sent to the
+Kafka topic.
+
+The Kafka connector does not allow the user to define which partition to send a
+message to. If a key is inserted with the message the producer will use a hash
+algorithm to decide which partition to send the message to. The same key will
+always be assigned the same partition.
+
+Row encoding
+------------
+
+Encoding allows :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to be used and defines how table
+columns in Presto map to Kafka key and message data.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* :ref:`raw encoder<raw-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to Kafka
+  message as raw bytes
+* :ref:`CSV encoder<csv-encoder>` - Kafka message is formatted as comma
+  separated value
+* :ref:`JSON encoder<json-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to JSON
+  fields
+* :ref:`Avro encoder<avro-encoder>` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro
+  fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` must be defined
+    for the encoder to work.
+
+.. _raw-encoder:
+
+raw encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The raw encoder formats the table columns as raw bytes using the mapping
+information specified in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`.
+
+The following field attributes are supported:
+
+* ``dataFormat`` - Selects the width of the column data type
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - ``<start>[:<end>]``; start and end position of bytes to convert
+
+The ``dataFormat`` attribute selects the number of bytes converted.
+If absent, ``BYTE`` is assumed. All values are signed.
+
+Supported values are:
+
+* ``BYTE`` - one byte
+* ``SHORT`` - two bytes (big-endian)
+* ``INT`` - four bytes (big-endian)
+* ``LONG`` - eight bytes (big-endian)
+* ``FLOAT`` - four bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+* ``DOUBLE`` - eight bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+
+The ``type`` attribute defines the Presto data type.
+
+Depending on Presto type assigned to column different values of ``dataFormat``
+can be used:
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      ``dataFormat`` values
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``INTEGER``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``
+``SMALLINT``                          ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``
+``TINYINT``                           ``BYTE``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``BYTE``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+The ``mapping`` attribute specifies the range of bytes in a key or
+message used for encoding. It can be one or two numbers separated by a colon
+(``<start>[:<end>]``).
+
+.. note::
+
+    For ``VARCHAR`` types a start and end position must be defined. Otherwise
+    there is no way to know how many bytes the message contains. The raw format
+    mapping information is static and cannot be dynamically changed to fit the
+    variable width of some Presto data types.
+
+If only a start position is given:
+
+* For fixed width types the appropriate number of bytes are used for the
+  specified ``dateFormat`` (see above).
+
+If start and end position are given, then:
+
+* For fixed width types the size must be equal to number of bytes used by
+  specified ``dataFormat``.
+* For ``VARCHAR`` all bytes between start (inclusive) and end (exclusive) are
+  used.
+
+.. note::
+
+    At the very least a start value must be present in the mapping for encoding
+    to work.
+
+Encoding scheme of numeric data types (``BIGINT``, ``INTEGER``, ``SMALLINT``,
+``TINYINT``, ``DOUBLE``) is straightforward. Table column values are encoded to
+bytes according to either:
+
+* big-endian encoding (for integer types)
+* IEEE 754 format for (for ``DOUBLE``).
+
+Example raw field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "raw",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "INTEGER",
+                    "dataFormat": "INT"
+                    "mapping": "8"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "SMALLINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "12"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field4",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR(6)",
+                    "dataFormat": "BYTE",
+                    "mapping": "20:26"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+.. note::
+
+    Columns should be defined in the same order they are mapped. There can be
+    no gaps or overlaps between column mappings. The width of the column as
+    defined by the column mapping must be equivalent to the width of the
+    ``dataFormat`` for all types except for variable width types.
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_raw_table (field1, field2, field3, field4)
+      VALUES (123456789, 123456, 1234, 'abcdef');
+
+.. note::
+
+    When inserting variable width types the value must be exactly equal to the
+    width defined in the table definition file. If the inserted value is longer
+    it gets truncated, resulting in data loss. If the inserted value is shorter
+    the decoder will not be able to properly read the value because there is no
+    defined padding character. Due to these constraints the encoder fails if the
+    width of the inserted value is not equal to the mapping width.
+
+.. _csv-encoder:
+
+CSV encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a line of
+comma-separated-values (CSV) using UTF-8 encoding.
+
+.. note::
+
+    The CSV line is formatted with a comma ',' as the column delimiter
+
+The ``type`` and ``mapping`` attributes must be defined for each field:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - The integer index of the column in the CSV line (the first
+  column is 0, the second is 1, and so on)

+``SMALLINT``                  Formatted using Java ``Short.toString()``
+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``
+``DOUBLE``                    Formatted using Java ``Double.toString()``
+``REAL``                      Formatted using Java ``Float.toString()``
+``BOOLEAN``                   Formatted using Java ``Boolean.toString()``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``  Unicode String encoded in UTF-8

+

+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "2"
+                }
+            ]
+    }

+

+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "json",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "field1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "field2"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "field3"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+

+* ``LONG`` - eight bytes (big-endian)
+* ``FLOAT`` - four bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+* ``DOUBLE`` - eight bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+
+The ``type`` attribute defines the Presto data type.
+
+Depending on Presto type assigned to column different values of ``dataFormat``
+can be used:
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      ``dataFormat`` values
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``INTEGER``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``
+``SMALLINT``                          ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``
+``TINYINT``                           ``BYTE``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``BYTE``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+The ``mapping`` attribute specifies the range of bytes in a key or
+message used for encoding. It can be one or two numbers separated by a colon
+(``<start>[:<end>]``).
+
+.. note::
+
+    For ``VARCHAR`` types a start and end position must be defined. Otherwise
+    there is no way to know how many bytes the message contains. The raw format
+    mapping information is static and cannot be dynamically changed to fit the
+    variable width of some Presto data types.
+
+If only a start position is given:
+
+* For fixed width types the appropriate number of bytes are used for the
+  specified ``dateFormat`` (see above).
+
+If start and end position are given, then:
+
+* For fixed width types the size must be equal to number of bytes used by
+  specified ``dataFormat``.
+* For ``VARCHAR`` all bytes between start (inclusive) and end (exclusive) are
+  used.
+
+.. note::
+
+    At the very least a start value must be present in the mapping for encoding
+    to work.
+
+Encoding scheme of numeric data types (``BIGINT``, ``INTEGER``, ``SMALLINT``,
+``TINYINT``, ``DOUBLE``) is straightforward. Table column values are encoded to
+bytes according to either:
+
+* big-endian encoding (for integer types)
+* IEEE 754 format for (for ``DOUBLE``).
+
+Example raw field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "raw",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "INTEGER",
+                    "dataFormat": "INT"
+                    "mapping": "8"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "SMALLINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "12"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field4",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR(6)",
+                    "dataFormat": "BYTE",
+                    "mapping": "20:26"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+.. note::
+
+    Columns should be defined in the same order they are mapped. There can be
+    no gaps or overlaps between column mappings. The width of the column as
+    defined by the column mapping must be equivalent to the width of the
+    ``dataFormat`` for all types except for variable width types.
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_raw_table (field1, field2, field3, field4)
+      VALUES (123456789, 123456, 1234, 'abcdef');
+
+.. note::
+
+    When inserting variable width types the value must be exactly equal to the
+    width defined in the table definition file. If the inserted value is longer
+    it gets truncated, resulting in data loss. If the inserted value is shorter
+    the decoder will not be able to properly read the value because there is no
+    defined padding character. Due to these constraints the encoder fails if the
+    width of the inserted value is not equal to the mapping width.
+
+.. _csv-encoder:
+
+CSV encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a line of
+comma-separated-values (CSV) using UTF-8 encoding.
+
+.. note::
+
+    The CSV line is formatted with a comma ',' as the column delimiter
+
+The ``type`` and ``mapping`` attributes must be defined for each field:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - The integer index of the column in the CSV line (the first
+  column is 0, the second is 1, and so on)
+
+``dataFormat`` and ``formatHint`` are not supported and must be omitted.
+
+The following table lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type``
+and encoding scheme:
+
+============================= ================================================
+Presto data type              Encoding rules
+============================= ================================================
+``BIGINT``                    Formatted using Java ``Long.toString()``
+``INTEGER``                   Formatted using Java ``Integer.toString()``
+``SMALLINT``                  Formatted using Java ``Short.toString()``
+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``
+``DOUBLE``                    Formatted using Java ``Double.toString()``
+``REAL``                      Formatted using Java ``Float.toString()``
+``BOOLEAN``                   Formatted using Java ``Boolean.toString()``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``  Unicode String encoded in UTF-8
+============================= ================================================
+
+Example CSV field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "csv",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "2"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_csv_table (field1, field2, field3)
+      VALUES (123456789, 'example text', TRUE);
+
+.. _json-encoder:
+
+JSON encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The JSON encoder maps table columns to JSON fields defined in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` according to
+:rfc:`4627`.
+
+For fields, the following attributes are supported:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto type of column.
+* ``mapping`` - slash-separated list of field names to select a field from the
+  JSON object
+
+The following Presto data types are supported by the JSON encoder
+
+* ``BIGINT``
+* ``INTEGER``
+* ``SMALLINT``
+* ``TINYINT``
+* ``DOUBLE``
+* ``REAL``
+* ``BOOLEAN``
+* ``VARCHAR``
+
+Example JSON field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "json",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "field1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "field2"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "field3"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_json_table (field1, field2, field3)
+      VALUES (123456789, 'example text', TRUE);
+
+.. _avro-encoder:
+
+Avro encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The Avro encoder serializes rows to Avro records as defined by the
+`Avro schema <http://avro.apache.org/docs/current/index.html>`_.
+Presto does not support schema-less Avro encoding.
+
+.. note::
+
+    The Avro schema is encoded with the table column values in each Kafka message
+
+The ``dataSchema`` must be defined in the table definition file to use the Avro
+encoder. It points to the location of the Avro schema file for the key or message
+
+Avro schema files can be retrieved via HTTP or HTTPS from remote server with the
+syntax:
+
+``"dataSchema": "http://example.org/schema/avro_data.avsc"``
+
+Local files need to be available on all Presto nodes and use an absolute path in
+the syntax, for example:
+
+``"dataSchema": "/usr/local/schema/avro_data.avsc"``
+
+The following field attributes are supported:
+
+* ``name`` - Name of the column in the Presto table.
+* ``type`` - Presto type of column.
+* ``mapping`` - slash-separated list of field names to select a field from the
+  Avro schema. If the field specified in ``mapping`` does not exist
+  in the original Avro schema then a write operation fails.

@@ -259,6 +264,430 @@ Field           Required  Type      Description
 
 There is no limit on field descriptions for either key or message.
 
+Kafka inserts
+-------------
+
+The Kafka connector supports the use of :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to write
+data to a Kafka topic. Table column data is mapped to Kafka messages as defined
+in the :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`. There are
+four supported data formats for key and message encoding:
+
+* :ref:`raw format<raw-encoder>`
+* :ref:`CSV format<csv-encoder>`
+* :ref:`JSON format<json-encoder>`
+* :ref:`Avro format<avro-encoder>`
+
+These data formats each have an encoder that handles mapping table column values.
+Table column values are mapped by the encoders and sent to Kafka topics as bytes.
+
+Presto supports at-least-once delivery for Kafka producers. This means that
+messages are guaranteed to be sent to Kafka topics at least once. If a producer
+acknowledgement times out or if the producer receives an error it might retry
+sending the message. This could result in a duplicate message being sent to the
+Kafka topic.
+
+The Kafka connector does not allow the user to define which partition to send a
+message to. If a key is inserted with the message the producer will use a hash
+algorithm to decide which partition to send the message to. The same key will
+always be assigned the same partition.
+
+Row encoding
+------------
+
+Encoding allows :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to be used and defines how table
+columns in Presto map to Kafka key and message data.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* :ref:`raw encoder<raw-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to Kafka
+  message as raw bytes
+* :ref:`CSV encoder<csv-encoder>` - Kafka message is formatted as comma
+  separated value
+* :ref:`JSON encoder<json-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to JSON
+  fields
+* :ref:`Avro encoder<avro-encoder>` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro
+  fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` must be defined
+    for the encoder to work.
+
+.. _raw-encoder:
+
+raw encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The raw encoder formats the table columns as raw bytes using the mapping
+information specified in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`.
+
+The following field attributes are supported:
+
+* ``dataFormat`` - Selects the width of the column data type
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - ``<start>[:<end>]``; start and end position of bytes to convert
+
+The ``dataFormat`` attribute selects the number of bytes converted.
+If absent, ``BYTE`` is assumed. All values are signed.
+
+Supported values are:
+
+* ``BYTE`` - one byte
+* ``SHORT`` - two bytes (big-endian)
+* ``INT`` - four bytes (big-endian)
+* ``LONG`` - eight bytes (big-endian)
+* ``FLOAT`` - four bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+* ``DOUBLE`` - eight bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+
+The ``type`` attribute defines the Presto data type.
+
+Depending on Presto type assigned to column different values of ``dataFormat``
+can be used:
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      ``dataFormat`` values
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``INTEGER``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``
+``SMALLINT``                          ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``
+``TINYINT``                           ``BYTE``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``BYTE``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+The ``mapping`` attribute specifies the range of bytes in a key or
+message used for encoding. It can be one or two numbers separated by a colon
+(``<start>[:<end>]``).
+
+.. note::
+
+    For ``VARCHAR`` types a start and end position must be defined. Otherwise
+    there is no way to know how many bytes the message contains. The raw format
+    mapping information is static and cannot be dynamically changed to fit the
+    variable width of some Presto data types.
+
+If only a start position is given:
+
+* For fixed width types the appropriate number of bytes are used for the
+  specified ``dateFormat`` (see above).
+
+If start and end position are given, then:
+
+* For fixed width types the size must be equal to number of bytes used by
+  specified ``dataFormat``.
+* For ``VARCHAR`` all bytes between start (inclusive) and end (exclusive) are
+  used.
+
+.. note::
+
+    At the very least a start value must be present in the mapping for encoding
+    to work.
+
+Encoding scheme of numeric data types (``BIGINT``, ``INTEGER``, ``SMALLINT``,
+``TINYINT``, ``DOUBLE``) is straightforward. Table column values are encoded to
+bytes according to either:
+
+* big-endian encoding (for integer types)
+* IEEE 754 format for (for ``DOUBLE``).
+
+Example raw field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "raw",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "INTEGER",
+                    "dataFormat": "INT"
+                    "mapping": "8"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "SMALLINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "12"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field4",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR(6)",
+                    "dataFormat": "BYTE",
+                    "mapping": "20:26"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+.. note::
+
+    Columns should be defined in the same order they are mapped. There can be
+    no gaps or overlaps between column mappings. The width of the column as
+    defined by the column mapping must be equivalent to the width of the
+    ``dataFormat`` for all types except for variable width types.
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_raw_table (field1, field2, field3, field4)
+      VALUES (123456789, 123456, 1234, 'abcdef');
+
+.. note::
+
+    When inserting variable width types the value must be exactly equal to the

+

+
+CSV encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a line of

+    The CSV line is formatted with a comma ',' as the column delimiter

+
+``dataFormat`` and ``formatHint`` are not supported and must be omitted.
+

+and encoding scheme:
+
+============================= ================================================
+Presto data type              Encoding rules
+============================= ================================================
+``BIGINT``                    Formatted using Java ``Long.toString()``
+``INTEGER``                   Formatted using Java ``Integer.toString()``
+``SMALLINT``                  Formatted using Java ``Short.toString()``
+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``
+``DOUBLE``                    Formatted using Java ``Double.toString()``
+``REAL``                      Formatted using Java ``Float.toString()``
+``BOOLEAN``                   Formatted using Java ``Boolean.toString()``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``  Unicode String encoded in UTF-8
+============================= ================================================
+
+Example CSV field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "csv",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "2"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_csv_table (field1, field2, field3)
+      VALUES (123456789, 'example text', TRUE);
+
+.. _json-encoder:
+
+JSON encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The JSON encoder maps table columns to JSON fields defined in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` according to
+:rfc:`4627`.
+
+For fields, the following attributes are supported:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto type of column.
+* ``mapping`` - slash-separated list of field names to select a field from the
+  JSON object
+
+The following Presto data types are supported by the JSON encoder
+
+* ``BIGINT``
+* ``INTEGER``
+* ``SMALLINT``
+* ``TINYINT``
+* ``DOUBLE``
+* ``REAL``
+* ``BOOLEAN``
+* ``VARCHAR``
+
+Example JSON field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "json",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "field1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "field2"
+                },
+                {

+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "field3"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_json_table (field1, field2, field3)

+.. _avro-encoder:
+
+Avro encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

+The Avro encoder serializes rows to Avro records as defined by the

+Encoding scheme of numeric data types (``BIGINT``, ``INTEGER``, ``SMALLINT``,
+``TINYINT``, ``DOUBLE``) is straightforward. Table column values are encoded to
+bytes according to either:
+
+* big-endian encoding (for integer types)
+* IEEE 754 format for (for ``DOUBLE``).
+
+Example raw field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "raw",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "INTEGER",
+                    "dataFormat": "INT"
+                    "mapping": "8"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "SMALLINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "12"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field4",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR(6)",
+                    "dataFormat": "BYTE",
+                    "mapping": "20:26"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+.. note::
+
+    Columns should be defined in the same order they are mapped. There can be
+    no gaps or overlaps between column mappings. The width of the column as
+    defined by the column mapping must be equivalent to the width of the
+    ``dataFormat`` for all types except for variable width types.
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_raw_table (field1, field2, field3, field4)
+      VALUES (123456789, 123456, 1234, 'abcdef');
+
+.. note::
+
+    When inserting variable width types the value must be exactly equal to the
+    width defined in the table definition file. If the inserted value is longer
+    it gets truncated, resulting in data loss. If the inserted value is shorter
+    the decoder will not be able to properly read the value because there is no
+    defined padding character. Due to these constraints the encoder fails if the
+    width of the inserted value is not equal to the mapping width.
+
+.. _csv-encoder:
+
+CSV encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a line of
+comma-separated-values (CSV) using UTF-8 encoding.
+
+.. note::
+
+    The CSV line is formatted with a comma ',' as the column delimiter
+
+The ``type`` and ``mapping`` attributes must be defined for each field:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - The integer index of the column in the CSV line (the first
+  column is 0, the second is 1, and so on)
+
+``dataFormat`` and ``formatHint`` are not supported and must be omitted.
+
+The following table lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type``
+and encoding scheme:
+
+============================= ================================================
+Presto data type              Encoding rules
+============================= ================================================
+``BIGINT``                    Formatted using Java ``Long.toString()``
+``INTEGER``                   Formatted using Java ``Integer.toString()``
+``SMALLINT``                  Formatted using Java ``Short.toString()``
+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``
+``DOUBLE``                    Formatted using Java ``Double.toString()``
+``REAL``                      Formatted using Java ``Float.toString()``
+``BOOLEAN``                   Formatted using Java ``Boolean.toString()``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``  Unicode String encoded in UTF-8
+============================= ================================================
+
+Example CSV field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "csv",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "2"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_csv_table (field1, field2, field3)
+      VALUES (123456789, 'example text', TRUE);
+
+.. _json-encoder:
+
+JSON encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The JSON encoder maps table columns to JSON fields defined in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` according to
+:rfc:`4627`.
+
+For fields, the following attributes are supported:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto type of column.
+* ``mapping`` - slash-separated list of field names to select a field from the
+  JSON object
+
+The following Presto data types are supported by the JSON encoder
+
+* ``BIGINT``
+* ``INTEGER``
+* ``SMALLINT``
+* ``TINYINT``
+* ``DOUBLE``
+* ``REAL``
+* ``BOOLEAN``
+* ``VARCHAR``
+
+Example JSON field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "json",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "field1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "field2"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "field3"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_json_table (field1, field2, field3)
+      VALUES (123456789, 'example text', TRUE);
+
+.. _avro-encoder:
+
+Avro encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The Avro encoder serializes rows to Avro records as defined by the
+`Avro schema <http://avro.apache.org/docs/current/index.html>`_.
+Presto does not support schema-less Avro encoding.
+
+.. note::
+
+    The Avro schema is encoded with the table column values in each Kafka message
+
+The ``dataSchema`` must be defined in the table definition file to use the Avro
+encoder. It points to the location of the Avro schema file for the key or message
+
+Avro schema files can be retrieved via HTTP or HTTPS from remote server with the
+syntax:
+
+``"dataSchema": "http://example.org/schema/avro_data.avsc"``
+
+Local files need to be available on all Presto nodes and use an absolute path in
+the syntax, for example:
+
+``"dataSchema": "/usr/local/schema/avro_data.avsc"``
+
+The following field attributes are supported:
+
+* ``name`` - Name of the column in the Presto table.
+* ``type`` - Presto type of column.
+* ``mapping`` - slash-separated list of field names to select a field from the
+  Avro schema. If the field specified in ``mapping`` does not exist
+  in the original Avro schema then a write operation fails.
+
+The following table lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type``
+for the equivalent Avro field type/s.
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      Avro data type
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``REAL``                              ``FLOAT``

@@ -259,6 +264,430 @@ Field           Required  Type      Description
 
 There is no limit on field descriptions for either key or message.
 
+Kafka inserts
+-------------
+
+The Kafka connector supports the use of :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to write
+data to a Kafka topic. Table column data is mapped to Kafka messages as defined
+in the :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`. There are
+four supported data formats for key and message encoding:
+
+* :ref:`raw format<raw-encoder>`
+* :ref:`CSV format<csv-encoder>`
+* :ref:`JSON format<json-encoder>`
+* :ref:`Avro format<avro-encoder>`
+
+These data formats each have an encoder that handles mapping table column values.
+Table column values are mapped by the encoders and sent to Kafka topics as bytes.
+
+Presto supports at-least-once delivery for Kafka producers. This means that
+messages are guaranteed to be sent to Kafka topics at least once. If a producer
+acknowledgement times out or if the producer receives an error it might retry
+sending the message. This could result in a duplicate message being sent to the
+Kafka topic.
+
+The Kafka connector does not allow the user to define which partition to send a
+message to. If a key is inserted with the message the producer will use a hash
+algorithm to decide which partition to send the message to. The same key will
+always be assigned the same partition.
+
+Row encoding
+------------
+
+Encoding allows :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to be used and defines how table
+columns in Presto map to Kafka key and message data.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* :ref:`raw encoder<raw-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to Kafka
+  message as raw bytes
+* :ref:`CSV encoder<csv-encoder>` - Kafka message is formatted as comma
+  separated value
+* :ref:`JSON encoder<json-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to JSON
+  fields
+* :ref:`Avro encoder<avro-encoder>` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro
+  fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` must be defined
+    for the encoder to work.
+
+.. _raw-encoder:
+
+raw encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The raw encoder formats the table columns as raw bytes using the mapping
+information specified in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`.
+
+The following field attributes are supported:
+
+* ``dataFormat`` - Selects the width of the column data type
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - ``<start>[:<end>]``; start and end position of bytes to convert
+
+The ``dataFormat`` attribute selects the number of bytes converted.
+If absent, ``BYTE`` is assumed. All values are signed.
+
+Supported values are:
+
+* ``BYTE`` - one byte
+* ``SHORT`` - two bytes (big-endian)
+* ``INT`` - four bytes (big-endian)
+* ``LONG`` - eight bytes (big-endian)
+* ``FLOAT`` - four bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+* ``DOUBLE`` - eight bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+
+The ``type`` attribute defines the Presto data type.
+
+Depending on Presto type assigned to column different values of ``dataFormat``
+can be used:
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      ``dataFormat`` values
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``INTEGER``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``
+``SMALLINT``                          ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``
+``TINYINT``                           ``BYTE``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``BYTE``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+The ``mapping`` attribute specifies the range of bytes in a key or
+message used for encoding. It can be one or two numbers separated by a colon
+(``<start>[:<end>]``).
+
+.. note::
+
+    For ``VARCHAR`` types a start and end position must be defined. Otherwise
+    there is no way to know how many bytes the message contains. The raw format
+    mapping information is static and cannot be dynamically changed to fit the
+    variable width of some Presto data types.
+
+If only a start position is given:
+
+* For fixed width types the appropriate number of bytes are used for the
+  specified ``dateFormat`` (see above).
+
+If start and end position are given, then:
+
+* For fixed width types the size must be equal to number of bytes used by
+  specified ``dataFormat``.
+* For ``VARCHAR`` all bytes between start (inclusive) and end (exclusive) are
+  used.
+
+.. note::
+
+    At the very least a start value must be present in the mapping for encoding
+    to work.
+
+Encoding scheme of numeric data types (``BIGINT``, ``INTEGER``, ``SMALLINT``,
+``TINYINT``, ``DOUBLE``) is straightforward. Table column values are encoded to
+bytes according to either:
+
+* big-endian encoding (for integer types)
+* IEEE 754 format for (for ``DOUBLE``).
+
+Example raw field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "raw",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "INTEGER",
+                    "dataFormat": "INT"
+                    "mapping": "8"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "SMALLINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "12"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field4",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR(6)",
+                    "dataFormat": "BYTE",
+                    "mapping": "20:26"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+.. note::
+
+    Columns should be defined in the same order they are mapped. There can be
+    no gaps or overlaps between column mappings. The width of the column as
+    defined by the column mapping must be equivalent to the width of the
+    ``dataFormat`` for all types except for variable width types.
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_raw_table (field1, field2, field3, field4)
+      VALUES (123456789, 123456, 1234, 'abcdef');
+
+.. note::
+
+    When inserting variable width types the value must be exactly equal to the
+    width defined in the table definition file. If the inserted value is longer
+    it gets truncated, resulting in data loss. If the inserted value is shorter
+    the decoder will not be able to properly read the value because there is no
+    defined padding character. Due to these constraints the encoder fails if the
+    width of the inserted value is not equal to the mapping width.
+
+.. _csv-encoder:
+
+CSV encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a line of
+comma-separated-values (CSV) using UTF-8 encoding.
+
+.. note::
+
+    The CSV line is formatted with a comma ',' as the column delimiter
+
+The ``type`` and ``mapping`` attributes must be defined for each field:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto data type

+  column is 0, the second is 1, and so on)
+
+``dataFormat`` and ``formatHint`` are not supported and must be omitted.
+
+The following table lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type``
+and encoding scheme:
+
+============================= ================================================
+Presto data type              Encoding rules
+============================= ================================================
+``BIGINT``                    Formatted using Java ``Long.toString()``
+``INTEGER``                   Formatted using Java ``Integer.toString()``
+``SMALLINT``                  Formatted using Java ``Short.toString()``
+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``
+``DOUBLE``                    Formatted using Java ``Double.toString()``
+``REAL``                      Formatted using Java ``Float.toString()``
+``BOOLEAN``                   Formatted using Java ``Boolean.toString()``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``  Unicode String encoded in UTF-8
+============================= ================================================
+
+Example CSV field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "csv",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "2"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_csv_table (field1, field2, field3)
+      VALUES (123456789, 'example text', TRUE);
+
+.. _json-encoder:
+
+JSON encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The JSON encoder maps table columns to JSON fields defined in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` according to
+:rfc:`4627`.
+
+For fields, the following attributes are supported:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto type of column.
+* ``mapping`` - slash-separated list of field names to select a field from the
+  JSON object
+
+The following Presto data types are supported by the JSON encoder
+
+* ``BIGINT``
+* ``INTEGER``
+* ``SMALLINT``
+* ``TINYINT``
+* ``DOUBLE``
+* ``REAL``
+* ``BOOLEAN``
+* ``VARCHAR``
+
+Example JSON field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "json",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "field1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "field2"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "field3"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_json_table (field1, field2, field3)

+
+.. _avro-encoder:
+
+Avro encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The Avro encoder serializes rows to Avro records as defined by the

+
+    The Avro schema is encoded with the table column values in each Kafka message

+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      Avro data type
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``

+    ``dataFormat`` for all types except for variable width types.
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_raw_table (field1, field2, field3, field4)
+      VALUES (123456789, 123456, 1234, 'abcdef');
+
+.. note::
+
+    When inserting variable width types the value must be exactly equal to the
+    width defined in the table definition file. If the inserted value is longer
+    it gets truncated, resulting in data loss. If the inserted value is shorter
+    the decoder will not be able to properly read the value because there is no
+    defined padding character. Due to these constraints the encoder fails if the
+    width of the inserted value is not equal to the mapping width.
+
+.. _csv-encoder:
+
+CSV encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a line of
+comma-separated-values (CSV) using UTF-8 encoding.
+
+.. note::
+
+    The CSV line is formatted with a comma ',' as the column delimiter
+
+The ``type`` and ``mapping`` attributes must be defined for each field:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - The integer index of the column in the CSV line (the first
+  column is 0, the second is 1, and so on)
+
+``dataFormat`` and ``formatHint`` are not supported and must be omitted.
+
+The following table lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type``
+and encoding scheme:
+
+============================= ================================================
+Presto data type              Encoding rules
+============================= ================================================
+``BIGINT``                    Formatted using Java ``Long.toString()``
+``INTEGER``                   Formatted using Java ``Integer.toString()``
+``SMALLINT``                  Formatted using Java ``Short.toString()``
+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``
+``DOUBLE``                    Formatted using Java ``Double.toString()``
+``REAL``                      Formatted using Java ``Float.toString()``
+``BOOLEAN``                   Formatted using Java ``Boolean.toString()``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``  Unicode String encoded in UTF-8
+============================= ================================================
+
+Example CSV field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "csv",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "2"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_csv_table (field1, field2, field3)
+      VALUES (123456789, 'example text', TRUE);
+
+.. _json-encoder:
+
+JSON encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The JSON encoder maps table columns to JSON fields defined in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` according to
+:rfc:`4627`.
+
+For fields, the following attributes are supported:
+
+* ``type`` - Presto type of column.
+* ``mapping`` - slash-separated list of field names to select a field from the
+  JSON object
+
+The following Presto data types are supported by the JSON encoder
+
+* ``BIGINT``
+* ``INTEGER``
+* ``SMALLINT``
+* ``TINYINT``
+* ``DOUBLE``
+* ``REAL``
+* ``BOOLEAN``
+* ``VARCHAR``
+
+Example JSON field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "json",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "mapping": "field1"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR",
+                    "mapping": "field2"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "BOOLEAN",
+                    "mapping": "field3"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_json_table (field1, field2, field3)
+      VALUES (123456789, 'example text', TRUE);
+
+.. _avro-encoder:
+
+Avro encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The Avro encoder serializes rows to Avro records as defined by the
+`Avro schema <http://avro.apache.org/docs/current/index.html>`_.
+Presto does not support schema-less Avro encoding.
+
+.. note::
+
+    The Avro schema is encoded with the table column values in each Kafka message
+
+The ``dataSchema`` must be defined in the table definition file to use the Avro
+encoder. It points to the location of the Avro schema file for the key or message
+
+Avro schema files can be retrieved via HTTP or HTTPS from remote server with the
+syntax:
+
+``"dataSchema": "http://example.org/schema/avro_data.avsc"``
+
+Local files need to be available on all Presto nodes and use an absolute path in
+the syntax, for example:
+
+``"dataSchema": "/usr/local/schema/avro_data.avsc"``
+
+The following field attributes are supported:
+
+* ``name`` - Name of the column in the Presto table.
+* ``type`` - Presto type of column.
+* ``mapping`` - slash-separated list of field names to select a field from the
+  Avro schema. If the field specified in ``mapping`` does not exist
+  in the original Avro schema then a write operation fails.
+
+The following table lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type``
+for the equivalent Avro field type/s.
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      Avro data type
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``REAL``                              ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BOOLEAN``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``STRING``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+Example Avro field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none

nodes.bodyText: Same comment

+Kafka inserts
+-------------
+
+The Kafka connector supports the use of :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to write
+data to a Kafka topic. Table column data is mapped to Kafka messages as defined
+in the :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`. There are
+four supported data formats for key and message encoding:
+
+* :ref:`raw format<raw-encoder>`
+* :ref:`CSV format<csv-encoder>`
+* :ref:`JSON format<json-encoder>`
+* :ref:`Avro format<avro-encoder>`
+
+These data formats each have an encoder that handles mapping table column values.
+Table column values are mapped by the encoders and sent to Kafka topics as bytes.
+
+Presto supports at-least-once delivery for Kafka producers. This means that
+messages are guaranteed to be sent to Kafka topics at least once. If a producer
+acknowledgement times out or if the producer receives an error it might retry
+sending the message. This could result in a duplicate message being sent to the
+Kafka topic.
+
+The Kafka connector does not allow the user to define which partition to send a
+message to. If a key is inserted with the message the producer will use a hash
+algorithm to decide which partition to send the message to. The same key will
+always be assigned the same partition.
+
+Row encoding
+------------
+
+Encoding allows :doc:`/sql/insert` statements to be used and defines how table
+columns in Presto map to Kafka key and message data.
+
+The Kafka connector contains the following encoders:
+
+* :ref:`raw encoder<raw-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to Kafka
+  message as raw bytes
+* :ref:`CSV encoder<csv-encoder>` - Kafka message is formatted as comma
+  separated value
+* :ref:`JSON encoder<json-encoder>` - Table columns are mapped to JSON
+  fields
+* :ref:`Avro encoder<avro-encoder>` - Kafka message is mapped to Avro
+  fields based on an Avro schema
+
+.. note::
+
+    A :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>` must be defined
+    for the encoder to work.
+
+.. _raw-encoder:
+
+raw encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The raw encoder formats the table columns as raw bytes using the mapping
+information specified in the
+:ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`.
+
+The following field attributes are supported:
+
+* ``dataFormat`` - Selects the width of the column data type
+* ``type`` - Presto data type
+* ``mapping`` - ``<start>[:<end>]``; start and end position of bytes to convert
+
+The ``dataFormat`` attribute selects the number of bytes converted.
+If absent, ``BYTE`` is assumed. All values are signed.
+
+Supported values are:
+
+* ``BYTE`` - one byte
+* ``SHORT`` - two bytes (big-endian)
+* ``INT`` - four bytes (big-endian)
+* ``LONG`` - eight bytes (big-endian)
+* ``FLOAT`` - four bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+* ``DOUBLE`` - eight bytes (IEEE 754 format)
+
+The ``type`` attribute defines the Presto data type.
+
+Depending on Presto type assigned to column different values of ``dataFormat``
+can be used:
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      ``dataFormat`` values
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``INTEGER``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``
+``SMALLINT``                          ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``
+``TINYINT``                           ``BYTE``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BYTE``, ``SHORT``, ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``BYTE``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+The ``mapping`` attribute specifies the range of bytes in a key or
+message used for encoding. It can be one or two numbers separated by a colon
+(``<start>[:<end>]``).
+
+.. note::
+
+    For ``VARCHAR`` types a start and end position must be defined. Otherwise
+    there is no way to know how many bytes the message contains. The raw format
+    mapping information is static and cannot be dynamically changed to fit the
+    variable width of some Presto data types.
+
+If only a start position is given:
+
+* For fixed width types the appropriate number of bytes are used for the
+  specified ``dateFormat`` (see above).
+
+If start and end position are given, then:
+
+* For fixed width types the size must be equal to number of bytes used by
+  specified ``dataFormat``.
+* For ``VARCHAR`` all bytes between start (inclusive) and end (exclusive) are
+  used.
+
+.. note::
+
+    At the very least a start value must be present in the mapping for encoding
+    to work.
+
+Encoding scheme of numeric data types (``BIGINT``, ``INTEGER``, ``SMALLINT``,
+``TINYINT``, ``DOUBLE``) is straightforward. Table column values are encoded to
+bytes according to either:
+
+* big-endian encoding (for integer types)
+* IEEE 754 format for (for ``DOUBLE``).
+
+Example raw field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "raw",
+            "fields": [
+                {
+                    "name": "field1",
+                    "type": "BIGINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "0"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field2",
+                    "type": "INTEGER",
+                    "dataFormat": "INT"
+                    "mapping": "8"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field3",
+                    "type": "SMALLINT",
+                    "dataFormat": "LONG",
+                    "mapping": "12"
+                },
+                {
+                    "name": "field4",
+                    "type": "VARCHAR(6)",
+                    "dataFormat": "BYTE",
+                    "mapping": "20:26"
+                }
+            ]
+    }
+
+.. note::
+
+    Columns should be defined in the same order they are mapped. There can be
+    no gaps or overlaps between column mappings. The width of the column as
+    defined by the column mapping must be equivalent to the width of the
+    ``dataFormat`` for all types except for variable width types.
+
+Example ``INSERT INTO`` query for the above table definition:
+
+.. code-block:: SQL
+
+    INSERT INTO example_raw_table (field1, field2, field3, field4)
+      VALUES (123456789, 123456, 1234, 'abcdef');
+
+.. note::
+
+    When inserting variable width types the value must be exactly equal to the
+    width defined in the table definition file. If the inserted value is longer
+    it gets truncated, resulting in data loss. If the inserted value is shorter
+    the decoder will not be able to properly read the value because there is no
+    defined padding character. Due to these constraints the encoder fails if the
+    width of the inserted value is not equal to the mapping width.
+

+

+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The CSV encoder formats the values for each row as a line of
+comma-separated-values (CSV) using UTF-8 encoding.

+The following table lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type``
+and encoding scheme:

+============================= ================================================

+``INTEGER``                   Formatted using Java ``Integer.toString()``

+``TINYINT``                   Formatted using Java ``Byte.toString()``

+.. _avro-encoder:
+
+Avro encoder
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+The Avro encoder serializes rows to Avro records as defined by the
+`Avro schema <http://avro.apache.org/docs/current/index.html>`_.
+Presto does not support schema-less Avro encoding.
+
+.. note::
+
+    The Avro schema is encoded with the table column values in each Kafka message

+The ``dataSchema`` must be defined in the table definition file to use the Avro
+encoder. It points to the location of the Avro schema file for the key or message

+Avro schema files can be retrieved via HTTP or HTTPS from remote server with the
+syntax:
+
+``"dataSchema": "http://example.org/schema/avro_data.avsc"``
+
+Local files need to be available on all Presto nodes and use an absolute path in
+the syntax, for example:
+
+``"dataSchema": "/usr/local/schema/avro_data.avsc"``
+
+The following field attributes are supported:
+
+* ``name`` - Name of the column in the Presto table.
+* ``type`` - Presto type of column.
+* ``mapping`` - slash-separated list of field names to select a field from the
+  Avro schema. If the field specified in ``mapping`` does not exist
+  in the original Avro schema then a write operation fails.

+The following table lists supported Presto types, which can be used in ``type``
+for the equivalent Avro field type/s.
+
+===================================== =======================================
+Presto data type                      Avro data type
+===================================== =======================================
+``BIGINT``                            ``INT``, ``LONG``
+``DOUBLE``                            ``DOUBLE``, ``FLOAT``
+``REAL``                              ``FLOAT``
+``BOOLEAN``                           ``BOOLEAN``
+``VARCHAR`` / ``VARCHAR(x)``          ``STRING``
+===================================== =======================================
+
+Example Avro field definition in a :ref:`table definition file<kafka-table-definition-files>`
+for a Kafka message:
+
+.. code-block:: none
+
+    "message": {
+            "dataFormat": "avro",
+            "dataSchema": "/avro_message_schema.avsc",
+            "fields": [
+                {

+                },

+                "name": "field2",
+                "type": "VARCHAR",
+                "mapping": "field2"
+                },

+                      "default": null
+                  }
+      ],
+      "doc:" : "A basic avro schema"
+    }
+
